body: I will take a look at the case @Computron010 reported, but definitely we need to fix this.

@Computron010 I cannot find a media file that fits to this case. It would be helpful if you could share me magnet uri if it's okay to you. So I can download using my account and study the case. Or you can provide API response including `medias` filed (with sensitive info redacted).
@wiserain I have invited you to collaborate on a private repo with a README with the media details.

As mentioned in #6765, the Pikpak backend uses a media link as a link for object opening/download. This is based on the assumption that Pikpak always serves original contents in the first item of media, i.e., `Medias[0]`. It is quite bold but holds in most case.

After examining the case @Computron010 reported, it looks like a server error. Both media links from `Medias[0]` and `Medias[1]` are pointing to the same file which is transcoded version of original media.

In this exceptional case, there's nothing we can do to check the validity of a media link before the actual download finished. So it is safe to remove the feature. I will send a PR to fix this.

issue.title: pikpak: add validity check when using a media link

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
<!--
Thank you very much for contributing code or documentation to rclone! Please
fill out the following questions to make it easier for us to review your
changes.

You do not need to check all the boxes below all at once, feel free to take
your time and add more commits. If you're done and ready for review, please
check the last box.
-->

#### What is the purpose of this change?

Before this change:

The Pikpak backend would always download the first media item whenever possible, regardless of whether or not it was linked to the original contents. This could lead to users downloading the wrong file, e.g. transcoded media.

Now:

We check the validity of a media link using the `fid` parameter in the link URL. This ensures that users always download the correct file object.

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

Closes #6992 

#### Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-new-feature-or-bug-fix).
- [x] I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
- [x] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [x] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [x] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)

body:
No matter how hard we check the index, there can be no valid link in `Medias[]`. This is exactly what you are suffering.

I have downloaded all four files using media links and one of them is supposed to be around 7GB but it actually is

![image](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/assets/20354654/b29a9e25-1015-4697-8c19-2728fbb5485c)

Note that media index is appended to filenames. In this case your code will never get you the 7GB original file.
That's fine. We should not use media links where there is no valid link, but I think we should still use them when it's possible to do so instead of removing the functionality entirely.

The problem is that we don't know whether one of media links is valid or not until we download it. Isn't it?

Btw, is there any reason to keep this functionality? If it is really beneficial we can make it opt-in feature later, something like `--pikpak-use-media-link`.

From observing the API response of the problematic file, the PikPak web UI does not give the user the option to stream in Original quality, but does so for other files. The argument I would make is, if the UI would present that option to the user, then we can safely assume that there is a valid link. I claim that the `IsVisible` property controls whether or not Original quality media links are valid when available. 

In my experience downloading files over media links provides significant speed increase when not, and as you mentioned before also allows additional parallel connections. With the regular download links using two connections on that 00003.m2ts file I can only get about 700 KB/s, but using media links with other 7GB files I can get 10 MB/s. 

Keeping it opt-in is not a bad idea either, the API might be unstable at this time.
I have confirmed meaningful speed increase when using a media link. Also found a better way to control the case. I will revise #6997 accordingly.
The PR has been merged. You may want to check the latest beta which will be available soon.
